definition: The science which deals with the physical structure and substance of the earth, their history, and the processes which act on them.
Politics, especially international relations, as influenced by geographical factors.
The science or practice of drawing maps.
The study of geometrical properties and spatial relations unaffected by the continuous change of shape or size of figures.
The subfield of geography that studies physical patterns and processes of the Earth.
The second-largest continent, connected to Asia by the Isthmus of Suez and lying between the Mediterranean Sea and the Atlantic and Indian Oceans.
The city or town that functions as the seat of government and administrative centre of a country or region.
Any of the world's main continuous expanses of land.
The largest continent with 60% of the earth's population.
A line notionally drawn on the earth equidistant from the poles, dividing the earth into northern and southern hemispheres.
A circle of constant longitude passing through a given place on the earth's surface and the terrestrial poles.
A river or stream flowing into a larger river or lake.
The angular distance of a place east or west of the Greenwich meridian, or west of the standard meridian of a celestial object, usually expressed in degrees and minutes.
An instrument containing a magnetized pointer which shows the direction of magnetic north and bearings from it.
An instrument containing a magnetized pointer which shows the direction of magnetic north and bearings from it.
An analemma is a diagram showing the position of the Sun in the sky.
The natural home or environment of an animal, plant, or other organism.
A stretch of salt water separated from the sea by a low sandbank or coral reef.
The state of the atmosphere at a particular place and seconds as regards.
A sudden violent shaking of the ground, typically causing great destruction, as a result of movements within the earth's crust or volcanic action.
The International System of Units derived unit of force.
German-born theoretical physicist who developed the theory of relativity, one of the two pillars of modern physics.
The branch of mechanics concerned with the motion of bodies under the action of forces.
Power derived from the utilization of physical or chemical resources, especially to provide light and heat or to work machines.
Amount of force exerted per area.
The branch of physical science that deals with the relations between heat and other forms of energy.
A property of matter by which it continues in its existing state of rest or uniform motion in a straight line, unless that state is changed by an external force.
The maximum extent of a vibration or oscillation, measured from the position of equilibrium.
The speed of something in a given direction.
English scientist who contributed to the study of electromagnetism and electrochemistry.
Geometry of motion.
A disturbance that travels through a medium, transporting energy from one location (its source) to another location without transporting matter.
The force that attracts a body towards the centre of the earth, or towards any other physical body having mass.
The quantity of motion of a moving body, measured as a product of its mass and velocity.

The process by which heat or electricity is directly transmitted through the material of a substance when there is a difference of temperature or of electrical potential between adjoining regions, without movement of the material.
A soft metal core made into a magnet by the passage of electric current through a coil surrounding it.
The emission of energy as electromagnetic waves or as moving subatomic particles, especially high-energy particles which cause ionization.
The fact or phenomenon of light, radio waves, etc. being deflected in passing obliquely through the interface between one medium and another or through a medium of varying density.
A space entirely devoid of matter.
The act or process by which an electric or magnetic effect is produced in an electrical conductor or magnetizable body when it is exposed to the influence or variation of a field of force.
This is the most common way to create a variable in JavaScript.
This keyword allows us to define our own functions in JavaScript.
A conditional statement is of the if-then format, and allows an application to decide between one or more courses of action, based on whether a particular condition is true.
A structure in code where you perform the same action or actions multiple times in a row.
The basic data structure in JavaScript. It have properties, also known as keys, to which are assigned values.
A data structure, which can store elements of different data type.
It is a traditionally a sequence of characters, either as a literal constant or as some kind of variable.
Data that is not an object and has no methods.
A list of steps to finish a task.
Finding and fixing errors in programs.
A loop with a predetermined beginning, end, and increment (step interval).
The first word of the name is lowercase and each new word after that is capitalized.
A repetitive action or command typically created with programming loops.
A way to get information out of a computer.
An extra piece of information passed to a function to customize it for a specific need.
A value that is passed between programs, subroutines or functions.
An expression used for creating statements that are either TRUE or FALSE.
A set of related objects with common properties.
A term used to describe a value that does not change throughout the execution of the program
A legal grouping of letters, symbols, and numbers being used to represent the value of one or more variables.
